results.title: A Bay in the balance
results.brief_description: In 1972, the Victorian Government responded to a conservation campaign and further industrial development in Westernport was halted. A major scientific study was initiated to examine how the relatively undeveloped bay functions and what future plans should be.

results.title: Batu caves
results.brief_description: A group of school children explores Batu Caves in Kuala Lumpur and discover interesting examples of Malayan wild life. Many varieties of bats are the chief inhabitants, while various insects, snails, crickets, centipedes, scorpions, white snakes and small crustaceans are also to be found. No other credits available.

results.title: Battle prelude
results.brief_description: With commentary by Wilfred Thomas, this is a record of the Australian Army Jungle-Training School at Canungra in Queensland during World War II. No other credits available.

results.title: The Battle of Wangapore
results.brief_description: In this satirical animation British troops under a typical Colonel Blimp test the turbanned and rebellious riff-raff from over the border and all with a stiff sense of propriety. The story tracks back to the good old days on the North West Frontier of India. An example of animation technique as used by an amateur production group. Animation by Richard Horn and Ken Clark. (See also Title Code 006110 “Let battle begin” for the history of the making of the cartoon.)

results.title: The Battle of Russia
results.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Why we fight”.
This epic film unfolds the great history of Russia, and the defeat of Hitler’s Nazi armies. The depiction of the mightiest battle in war history, with a human life toll of 20 million Russians and 10 million Germans, becomes more than a first hand record of war; it is also an ode to a people’s courage and self sacrifice, and the end of Hitler’s “Mein Kampf”. Historic film sequences of “The Seige of Leningrad” features the miracle of a “frozen lake” which becomes a rescue highway for a city surrounded and doomed, an event which turned the tide of World War II.

results.title: The Battle of Britain
results.creator_credit: Anthony Veiller, Frank Capra and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Why we fight”.
Illustrates the German air attack on Britain, particularly London, by the use of film shot during World War II. The role of civilians in the Battle of Britain is highlighted. Concentrates on the Blitz in London and Coventry after Dunkirk, combining actuality footage with many extracts from fiction films. This film is credited with reducing anti-British sentiment among American forces.

results.title: Battle for the Bulge
results.brief_description: Uses location filming and historical footage to document the ‘Battle for the Bulge’, the last big German offensive in World War II. Portrays the heroism, as well as the confusion and humiliation, that characterised both the Allied and German troops.

results.title: Battle for bread
results.creator_credit: Richard De Rochemont, March of Time, Inc. and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: The film stresses the importance of food in a world that has never produced enough for everyone, and describes the efforts of FAO to stimulate food production in many countries. After a preliminary survey of the food problem in war-torn countries, the film describes the working of the FAO program; agricultural machinery to China, international conferences on poison sprays for insects, the fight against animal diseases, encouragement to farmers to grow new kinds of crops.

results.title: Bats, birds and bionics
results.creator_credit: John MacDonald, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Demonstrates the application of the principles of natural systems in living animals such as bats, rattlesnakes, frogs and rats, to engineering devices to guide blind persons, self guiding missiles, photoelectric scanners capable of distinguishing shapes and bionic computers designed to learn and to control man-like robots. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.
